sect1.title: Preparing your Images for the web
sect1.para: The most purpose Gimp is used for, is to prepare the images for adding them to your web site. This means, that the images should look nicely by half the size the image is created. This little step by step guide will tell you, how you'll achieve a smaller file size with the (mostly) the same picture.

step.para: First open the image as usual. I opened our Wilber as an example image.

caption.para: The wilber opened in the RGBA mode.

step.para: The image is now in RGB mode with an additional alpha channel. Mostly it isn't needed to have an alpha channel for your web image. You can remove the Alpha channel by flattening the Image.
After flattening, you are able to save the image for your homepage.

sect2.title: Squeezing Filesize a bit more
sect2.para: If you want to squeeze your image a bit more, you've to convert your image to Indexe mode. However, converting images with smooth color transition or gradients are not suitable for converting them to indexed. Well, lets try to convert the image.

caption.para: The indexed image can look a bit grainy. The left image is the wilber in original size, the right one zoomed in by 300 percent.

step.para: Use the Convert Mode Dialog to convert your RGB image to indexed mode.
After converting to indexed, you are once again able to save your image.
